description:
Leuciscus leuciscus, commonly known as the common dace or dace, is a freshwater fish species belonging to the family Cyprinidae. It is native to Europe, found in rivers, streams, and lakes across the continent.

The common dace is a small to medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths between 10-25 cm. It has a slender, streamlined body shape with a slightly upturned mouth and small scales covering its body. The coloration of the dace can vary, but it is typically olive or brown on the back, with silvery-white sides and a white or yellowish belly.

Dace are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of aquatic invertebrates, small crustaceans, and plant material. They are an important prey species for larger predatory fish, birds, and other aquatic predators.

Leuciscus leuciscus plays a significant role in the freshwater ecosystems they inhabit, contributing to the overall biodiversity and food web dynamics. They are also of recreational importance, as they are commonly targeted by anglers for their fighting ability and as a food source.

The common dace is generally considered a species of least concern, with stable populations throughout much of its native range. However, it may face threats from habitat degradation, pollution, and the introduction of non-native species in some regions.
